name: Laptop Hardware Test Plan
description: Automated electrical measurements for laptops: battery health, USB PD charging, power draw, DC barrel jack voltage
safetyWarnings: Do NOT probe internal battery leads unless device is disassembled
Laptop chargers can supply up to 140W - handle with care
Ensure proper ventilation during power draw testing
Check for battery swelling before applying power

steps.name: Charger Output Voltage
steps.description: Measure charger output voltage at the DC jack or USB-C port. Verify correct voltage for the laptop model.
steps.setupInstructions: For USB-C: use PD tester inline. For barrel jack: measure DC voltage at plug tip (+) to barrel (-) without laptop connected.

steps.name: Total Power Draw
steps.description: Measure AC power consumption from the wall during normal operation (browsing, not under load).
steps.setupInstructions: Connect laptop charger through AC power meter. Boot laptop to desktop. Record power draw after 60 seconds of idle.

steps.name: Battery Voltage
steps.description: Measure battery pack voltage. Compare to expected voltage for cell count (3S = 11.1V, 4S = 14.8V nominal).
steps.setupInstructions: If battery is removable or accessible, measure across battery pack terminals. For sealed designs, rely on OS-reported battery voltage.

steps.name: Charging Current
steps.description: Measure current drawn from charger while laptop is charging. Verify charger is delivering expected amperage.
steps.setupInstructions: Use USB PD tester inline for USB-C chargers, or clamp current clamp on DC cable for barrel jack chargers.

steps.name: USB-C PD Port Test
steps.description: Verify USB-C port supports Power Delivery and negotiates correct voltage profiles.
steps.setupInstructions: Connect USB-C PD tester to laptop USB-C port (not all ports may support PD). Observe negotiated voltage profile.
